ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Basic Russian conjugation, ability to converse

I was able to learn the basics behind the Russian language such as the Russian alphabet, Russian nouns, Russian verbs, and Russian grammar. I definitely worked on both my long term and short term memory skills due to the unit tests and vocabulary quizzes. Some insights I made from this course is that the Russian language is actually very easy to use to its many connections with my native tongue, Spanish.
I learned how to read, speak, and write a not inconsiderable amount of the Russian language without any previous experience.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course could be improved by more conversation in class as opposed to simply exercises from the book.

One strength is that we are able to practice our grammar and pronunciation during zoom calls. Another strength is being exposed to Russian culture through anecdotes from the professor and TA or through exposure to Russian music and poetry.  A weakness of the course is
The course had good material which we could learn from and a great professor and Teaching Fellow. I have no suggestions for improvement.

I was worried that the online format would make it difficult for me to start learning a new language, but Professor Titus and Chloe encouraged active participation by asking each of us to speak in Russian at the beginning of class, calling on people to answer questions from exercises, and splitting us into breakout rooms. Overall, I think this course did an excellent job of teaching fundamental Russian grammar. At the same time, the introduction to the Russian alphabet at the beginning of the course felt a bit chaotic. Professor Titus showed us how to write a few letters in cursive, but I would have appreciated it if we had gone through the entire alphabet in order (for both the printed and cursive alphabets). Even if we had to memorize the alphabets on our own, it would have been helpful to have at least some sort of systematic introduction to the language.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The way things were often divided in breakout rooms, there would always be one or two groups of students who had discussions in Russian without the presence of a TA or the professor, which led to a lot of mistakes being left uncorrected. If the group could only be divided into two then that would probably be better.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Take this course if you want to learn Russian. Professor Titus is wonderful.

Yes, this class is amazing for anyone looking to experience a new language without having to worry about overcoming major hurdles. I love that this course is meant for every day which helps solidify all the lessons.
If the student sought to learn Russian in a supportive atmosphere and was willing to put in the daily work, then I would recommend this course to them.

Yes! Russian is such a beautiful language, and although it may be harder to pick up than a romance language, I think it's completely worth the effort. If you stick with it, you'll gain access to an incredible body of literature and a rich culture, one that many Americans don't care about or fully understand.
